qas.question: What accusations does the Watch Tower Society reject?

answers.text: that it is a false prophet

qas.question: What does George D. Chryssides suggest the changing views and dates of the Jehovah's Witnesses can be attributed to changed understandings of?
What profession does Andrew Holden smugly self-identify as?
How long ago was the foundation of the Jehovah's Witnesses movement?
What have Jehovah's Witnesses maintained we are living on the precipice of since their formation?
What religion is George D. Chryssides?
What is George D. Chryssides occupation?
Since what year has Andrew Holden been a sociologist?
In what year was the Watch Tower Society founded?
Who argues it is foolish to not believe that the Witnesses set end dates of civilization just to get additional members?

context: The Watch Tower Society rejects accusations <a0_0>that it is a false prophet<a0_0/>, stating that its teachings are not inspired or infallible, and that it has not claimed its predictions were "the words of Jehovah." <b9_0>George D. Chryssides<b9_0/> has suggested that with the exception of statements about <b8_0>1914<b8_0/>, 1925 and <b7_0>1975<b7_0/>, the changing views and dates of the <b5_0>Jehovah's Witnesses<b5_0/> are largely attributable to changed understandings of <a1_0>biblical chronology<a1_0/> than to failed predictions. Chryssides further states, "it is therefore simplistic and naïve to view the Witnesses as a group that continues to set a single end-date that fails and then devise a new one, as many counter-cultists do." However, <a2_0><b6_0>sociologist<b6_0/><a2_0/> Andrew Holden states that since the foundation of the movement <a3_0>around 140 years ago<a3_0/>, "Witnesses have maintained that we are living on the precipice of <a4_0>the end of time<a4_0/>."
